title: Responsible Alcohol Service
legalBasis: Law 5/2018 on physical activity and sport (varies by region); Law 33/2011 General Public Health Law; Law 1/2023 on advertising alcoholic beverages; Law 26/2015 on childhood and adolescence protection; Regional alcohol service laws (e.g., Catalonia Law 10/1991, Madrid Law 5/2002); Penal Code Articles 368, 379
summary:
Responsible alcohol service is both a legal requirement and an ethical responsibility for all hospitality workers who serve alcoholic beverages. Spanish law establishes multiple obligations and prohibitions regarding alcohol sales and service: absolute prohibition on serving alcohol to minors (persons under 18 years), prohibition on serving alcohol to visibly intoxicated persons, restrictions on alcohol advertising and promotions, specific requirements for certain licensed premises, and criminal liability for serving alcohol in ways that enable serious harm. Violations can result in administrative fines for the establishment, personal liability for the server, license suspension or revocation, and in extreme cases criminal prosecution.

Beyond legal compliance, responsible service reflects professional standards and social responsibility. Excessive alcohol consumption contributes to public health problems, traffic accidents, violence, and social disorder. Hospitality workers serving alcohol have a degree of control over these outcomes through their service decisions. Responsible service means understanding alcohol's effects on the body and behavior, recognizing signs of intoxication, knowing how to refuse service diplomatically but firmly when necessary, understanding your legal rights and protections when refusing service, and managing difficult situations involving intoxicated customers without escalating conflict.

Spanish regulation of alcohol service varies significantly by autonomous community. Each region has its own alcohol laws establishing licensing requirements, service restrictions, hours of operation, and penalties. Some regions (Asturias, Galicia) have stricter regulations including limits on happy hours and drink promotions. Others (Balearic Islands, Catalonia) have specific laws addressing tourist areas and nightlife. Hospitality workers must know the specific regulations applicable in their region, not just general national law. This guide covers general principles applicable across Spain; consult regional regulations for specific local requirements.

The responsibility for legal compliance rests primarily with the establishment and management, but individual servers also face potential liability. Serving a minor can result in fines to both the establishment and the individual server. Serving an intoxicated person who then causes an accident can create civil liability and potentially criminal liability in extreme cases. Understanding responsible service protects you legally, protects your customers from harm, and protects your establishment's license and reputation.
keyPoints: Never serve alcohol to anyone under 18 years — check ID if age is uncertain; valid ID includes DNI, NIE, passport, or driving license
Serving alcohol to minors can result in fines of €600-30,000 to the establishment and €600-3,000 to the individual server
Recognize signs of intoxication: slurred speech, unsteady gait, aggressive behavior, impaired judgment, drowsiness
You have the legal right and obligation to refuse service to intoxicated persons; management must support this decision
When refusing service, be polite but firm; offer non-alcoholic alternatives and food; do not debate or argue
Never encourage excessive drinking through promotions, drinking games, or peer pressure
Offer water and food to customers consuming alcohol; food slows alcohol absorption
Be aware of drink spiking risks; never leave drinks unattended and watch for suspicious behavior
If a customer becomes aggressive or refuses to leave, call security or police rather than confronting physically
Know your establishment's policies on ID checking, service refusal, and handling intoxicated customers

sections.heading: 1. Legal Framework and Regional Variations
sections.content:
Spanish alcohol regulation is complex due to division of competencies between national and regional governments. National law (primarily through health and advertising legislation) establishes general principles: prohibition on serving minors under 18, restrictions on alcohol advertising, and general public health protections. However, detailed regulation of alcohol service — licensing, permitted hours, service restrictions, administrative penalties — is primarily regional competence. Each autonomous community has its own alcohol law (Ley sobre prevención del consumo de bebidas alcohólicas, régimen sancionador, etc.) with specific requirements.

This creates significant variation across Spain. For example, Asturias prohibits happy hours and drink promotions; Catalonia requires prominent health warning signage in licensed premises; the Balearic Islands have special regulations for tourist areas limiting pub crawls and street drinking; Galicia restricts operating hours for certain license types; Madrid has specific rules for terraces and outdoor service. Hospitality workers must know their regional regulations, not just general principles. Establishments operating in tourist areas or near regional borders should be particularly careful about regulatory differences.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Prohibition on Serving Minors
subsections.content:
The absolute prohibition on selling or serving alcohol to persons under 18 is universal across Spain and established by both national health law and regional alcohol laws. This prohibition applies to all alcoholic beverages (beer, wine, spirits, mixed drinks) regardless of alcohol content, and to all service contexts (bars, restaurants, nightclubs, off-license sales, events). There are no exceptions for parental permission, religious ceremonies (outside of church services), or any other circumstances in public commercial contexts.

Violations carry serious penalties. Administrative fines for serving minors typically range from €600 to €30,000 for the establishment, with higher penalties for repeated violations. Individual servers can also be fined personally, typically €600-3,000. Beyond fines, establishments face potential license suspension (days to months depending on severity and recidivism) or permanent license revocation for repeated or egregious violations. In cases where serving minors leads to serious harm (alcohol poisoning, traffic accident), criminal liability may arise under Penal Code provisions for reckless endangerment or injury.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Prohibition on Serving Intoxicated Persons
subsections.content:
Most regional alcohol laws prohibit serving additional alcohol to persons who are visibly intoxicated (en estado de embriaguez). This prohibition protects both the intoxicated person (preventing further impairment and alcohol poisoning) and the public (reducing drunk driving, violence, and disorder). The standard is 'visible intoxication' — obvious signs observable by a reasonable person, not medical or scientific determination of blood alcohol content. Servers must make judgment calls based on customer behavior and appearance.

Liability for serving intoxicated persons extends beyond administrative penalties. Civil liability can arise if an intoxicated patron causes harm to others (traffic accident, assault) and it can be shown the establishment continued serving despite visible intoxication. Spanish courts have held establishments partially liable in cases where staff ignored obvious intoxication and the patron subsequently caused injury. Criminal liability is theoretically possible in extreme cases involving reckless disregard for obvious danger. While such criminal cases are rare, the civil and administrative liability risks are significant and real. Moreover, professional ethics and social responsibility require refusing service to protect vulnerable intoxicated individuals from harm.

subsections.heading: 1.3 Advertising and Promotion Restrictions
subsections.content:
Alcohol advertising and promotion is regulated by national Law 1/2023 and regional laws. Prohibited practices include advertising targeting minors (use of child-appealing imagery, characters, or themes), promoting alcohol in contexts associated with minors (schools, playgrounds, children's events), associating alcohol with improved physical performance, success, or social status, and in some regions, happy hours, quantity discounts (e.g., 2-for-1), or drinking games. These restrictions apply to formal advertising (posters, social media, TV ads) and in-premises promotions.

Hospitality workers should be aware of promotional restrictions when implementing marketing campaigns or in-house promotions. Consult regional regulations before launching any alcohol promotion. In regions like Asturias or Galicia with strict promotional bans, even common practices like happy hours may be prohibited. Beyond legal compliance, responsible establishments avoid promotions that encourage excessive or rapid drinking: drinking contests, extreme quantity discounts, promotions rewarding speed of consumption, or combining alcohol with activities that increase injury risk. These practices increase intoxication, disorder, and liability even where not explicitly illegal.

sections.heading: 2. Age Verification and ID Checking
sections.content:
Given the absolute prohibition on serving minors and the significant penalties for violations, robust age verification procedures are essential. The fundamental principle is simple: if you have any doubt about whether a customer is 18 or older, you must check valid identification before serving alcohol. While this may seem straightforward, practical implementation requires clear policies, consistent enforcement, and training in how to check ID effectively and handle customer resistance.

Establishments should adopt clear ID checking policies: many use a 'Challenge 25' or 'Challenge 30' approach (request ID from anyone who appears under 25 or 30 years, providing a buffer above the legal minimum of 18). This prevents the difficult judgment call of trying to determine exact age. Policies should specify which forms of ID are acceptable, what to do if a customer refuses to show ID, and how to handle suspected fake IDs. All staff must be trained in the policy and supported by management when enforcing it.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Valid Forms of Identification
subsections.content:
Acceptable ID documents in Spain for age verification include DNI (Documento Nacional de Identidad) for Spanish citizens, NIE (Número de Identidad de Extranjero) card for foreign residents, passport (Spanish or foreign), and European driving license (carnet de conducir). These documents are government-issued with photographs and dates of birth, making them reliable for age verification. Some establishments also accept European national ID cards from other EU countries. Student IDs, library cards, or non-government-issued documents are not acceptable as sole age verification.

When checking ID, verify the photograph matches the person presenting it (facial features, gender, approximate age in photo matches current appearance), check the date of birth and calculate the person's current age (they must be 18 or older), check that the document appears genuine (not obviously fake, tampered with, or expired), and if you have any doubt about authenticity or whether the person is the document holder, politely refuse service and explain you cannot verify age. Do not attempt to be an expert in fake ID detection — if something seems wrong, err on caution and refuse service.

subsections.heading: 2.2 How to Request ID Diplomatically
subsections.content:
Requesting ID can sometimes offend customers who believe they obviously look over 18. Handle ID requests professionally and consistently. Establish a routine approach: 'I need to see your ID please' or 'Can I see your ID?' stated matter-of-factly, not apologetically. If the customer objects ('I'm obviously over 18,' 'This is insulting,' etc.), explain politely: 'It's our policy to check ID for anyone who looks under 25/30, I'm sure you understand,' or 'It's the law that we verify age, I need to see your ID.' Do not make it personal or debatable. If the customer refuses, politely decline service: 'I'm sorry, without ID I cannot serve you alcohol. I can offer you non-alcoholic drinks.'

Consistency is key to reducing conflict. If you check ID for some young-appearing customers but not others, those checked may feel singled out or discriminated against. Checking all customers who appear under your establishment's threshold (e.g., Challenge 25) provides objective justification. Train all staff to use the same approach and threshold. Display signage informing customers of the policy: 'We operate Challenge 25 — please have ID ready if you appear under 25.' This sets expectations and reduces surprise when ID is requested.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Dealing with Fake or Questionable IDs
subsections.content:
Fake IDs range from obvious crude forgeries to sophisticated counterfeits. Servers are not expected to be forensic document examiners, but you should be aware of common signs of fake IDs: mismatched or poor-quality photographs, incorrect or obviously altered dates of birth, unusual card thickness, texture, or materials, misspellings or formatting errors, and holograms or security features that appear wrong or missing. If an ID appears suspicious, examine it more carefully, compare features to a genuine ID example (many establishments keep reference examples), and if doubt remains, politely refuse service explaining that you cannot verify the document's authenticity.

Never confiscate suspected fake IDs — you are not a law enforcement officer and taking someone's document (even a suspected fake) can create legal issues. Instead, refuse service and explain you cannot accept the document for age verification. If a customer becomes aggressive when you refuse service due to suspected fake ID, do not escalate; politely end the interaction and call security or management. If you have strong reason to believe a minor is using fake ID to obtain alcohol systematically, document the incident and report to management who may decide to inform authorities. However, individual servers should focus on refusing service, not investigating or confronting suspected fake ID users.

sections.heading: 3. Recognizing Intoxication
sections.content:
Identifying intoxication requires observing customer behavior, speech, and physical coordination. Alcohol affects the central nervous system progressively: at low levels (blood alcohol 0.02-0.05%) effects are subtle (mild euphoria, slight relaxation), at moderate levels (0.05-0.10%) impairment becomes more obvious (reduced inhibition, mild coordination problems, louder speech), at higher levels (0.10-0.20%) intoxication is clear (significant coordination impairment, slurred speech, impaired judgment, emotional instability), and at very high levels (above 0.20%) severe intoxication occurs (confusion, inability to walk, risk of alcohol poisoning). Servers need to recognize moderate-to-higher intoxication levels where service should be refused.

Intoxication signs vary by individual due to tolerance (regular drinkers show less obvious impairment at given blood alcohol levels), body size and composition (larger people metabolize alcohol faster), gender (women generally reach higher blood alcohol on same alcohol intake), food consumption (food in stomach slows absorption), and mixing of alcohol and other substances. Despite this variation, certain behavioral and physical signs reliably indicate intoxication requiring service refusal. Servers should monitor customers throughout their visit, not just when orders are placed, to notice progressive intoxication.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Physical Signs of Intoxication
subsections.content:
Observe customer physical coordination and appearance for signs including unsteady gait (stumbling, bumping into furniture, difficulty walking straight), poor fine motor control (difficulty handling money or card, dropping items, spilling drinks), slurred or slow speech (words running together, difficulty articulating, slower than normal speech), glassy or unfocused eyes (difficulty maintaining eye contact, eyes appear dull or red), flushed face (reddening of face and neck from vasodilation), and drowsiness (head nodding, difficulty staying awake, closing eyes). These signs typically appear at blood alcohol levels above 0.10% and indicate service should be refused.

Physical signs should be evaluated in context. Some medical conditions or disabilities can mimic intoxication signs (neurological conditions, mobility impairments, speech impediments, fatigue). If you observe apparent intoxication signs but have reason to believe they may result from medical issues, approach tactfully: 'I noticed you seem unsteady, are you feeling alright? I want to make sure you're safe.' If the person explains a medical condition, apologize for the concern and use judgment. However, if someone is objectively impaired (regardless of cause), you may still need to refuse alcohol service and potentially offer assistance. Your primary concern is customer safety, not making definitive diagnoses.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Behavioral Signs of Intoxication
subsections.content:
Behavioral changes often appear before obvious physical impairment and can be early warning signs. Watch for increased volume (talking or laughing louder than previously or than social context warrants), overly friendly or inappropriate behavior (becoming excessively familiar with staff or other customers, invading personal space, inappropriate touching or comments), mood swings (sudden shifts from happy to sad or angry, emotional lability), argumentative or aggressive behavior (picking fights, confrontational responses to minor issues, hostile tone), impaired judgment (making obviously poor decisions, taking risks, inappropriate spending), and repetitive behavior (telling same story multiple times, repeatedly ordering same drink immediately after finishing previous one).

Behavioral intoxication signs can be subtle, especially in crowded noisy environments. Train yourself to notice changes in individual customer behavior over time: a customer who was quiet and reserved on arrival but becomes loud and aggressive after several drinks is showing behavioral intoxication. Contextual awareness helps: in a nightclub, loud energetic behavior is normal; in a quiet wine bar, the same behavior is concerning. Trust your professional judgment. If customer behavior makes you uncomfortable or concerned, that is valid reason to consider refusing further service even if you cannot point to specific textbook intoxication signs.

subsections.heading: 3.3 Counting Drinks and Time Factors
subsections.content:
While intoxication depends on many factors beyond drink count, monitoring consumption helps identify risks. Standard drink sizes in Spain typically contain approximately 10 grams of pure alcohol: a caña (small beer, approximately 200ml) contains ~8g, a wine glass (100-150ml) contains ~10-12g, a shot of spirits (40-50ml) contains ~12-16g. General guidelines suggest that consuming more than 2-3 standard drinks per hour exceeds the liver's ability to metabolize alcohol, leading to increasing blood alcohol.

If you notice a customer consuming drinks rapidly (ordering next drink before finishing previous, drinking shots quickly, ordering multiple drinks at once for solo consumption), they are at high risk of sudden intoxication. Time also matters: alcohol takes 30-60 minutes to reach peak blood concentration after consumption. A customer who seems fine while ordering their fourth drink in 90 minutes may become obviously intoxicated 30 minutes later as earlier drinks take full effect. This delayed effect requires anticipatory judgment: if consumption rate suggests likely future intoxication, consider slowing service (longer gaps between drinks, suggesting food or water) before intoxication becomes obvious.

sections.heading: 4. Refusing Service Professionally
sections.content:
Refusing alcohol service is legally required when customers are underage or intoxicated, but it can be one of the most challenging aspects of hospitality work. Refused customers may become angry, argumentative, or aggressive. Servers worry about confrontation, complaints, or loss of tips. However, refusing service is a legal obligation that management must support. You cannot be penalized by your employer for refusing service in good faith compliance with law. Moreover, proper training in how to refuse service diplomatically reduces conflict and makes this difficult responsibility more manageable.

Successful service refusal combines firmness (clear, non-negotiable decision) with politeness (respectful tone, empathy for customer disappointment) and offers alternatives (non-alcoholic drinks, food, assistance calling taxi). The goal is to de-escalate potential conflict while maintaining the refusal. Never debate, argue, or allow yourself to be pressured into reversing a refusal decision based on sound judgment. Once you have refused service, stand by that decision. Backing down when customers argue undermines your authority and encourages customers to argue every time.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Diplomatic Refusal Techniques
subsections.content:
When refusing service, approach calmly and speak privately if possible (taking customer aside rather than announcing refusal in front of their group reduces embarrassment and defensive reaction). Use clear, simple language: 'I'm sorry, I cannot serve you any more alcohol' or 'I need to see ID before I can serve you alcohol.' State the reason briefly: 'You seem to have had enough to drink,' 'I need to verify your age,' or simply 'It's our policy.' Avoid lengthy explanations or justifications that invite debate.

Offer alternatives immediately: 'I can get you water, soft drink, or coffee' or 'Can I call you a taxi?' This shifts the interaction from pure refusal to offering help. Use empathetic language: 'I understand you're disappointed, but I'm concerned for your safety' or 'I'm sure you understand, we have to follow the law.' Remain polite but firm. If the customer argues, repeat your decision calmly: 'I understand, but my decision stands.' Do not engage in debate about how intoxicated they are, whether you are being fair, or comparisons to other customers. A simple 'I've made my decision for safety reasons, I'm not able to serve you' closes the discussion.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Dealing with Difficult Reactions
subsections.content:
Some customers will react negatively to service refusal. Common reactions include anger and aggression ('You can't refuse me! This is discrimination!'), arguments about intoxication ('I'm not drunk, you're wrong'), attempts to bargain ('Just one more drink, then I'll leave'), threats ('I'll complain to your manager / leave a bad review'), and attempts to circumvent refusal (asking different server, having friend order for them). Each requires specific response.

For anger and aggression, remain calm, do not mirror the customer's emotion, speak quietly (forcing them to quiet to hear you), and if aggression escalates, call security or manager rather than continuing to engage. For arguments about intoxication, do not debate: 'I've assessed the situation and made my decision based on your safety.' For bargaining, maintain refusal: 'I understand, but my answer is no.' For threats, stay professional: 'You're welcome to speak with my manager, but my decision is final.' For circumvention attempts, alert other servers and management that you have refused service to specific customer so others do not inadvertently serve them.

subsections.heading: 4.3 When to Involve Management and Security
subsections.content:
Involve management when customer refuses to accept your service refusal and continues to argue or demand service, customer becomes aggressive or threatening, you are uncertain whether to refuse service and want support for your judgment, customer demands to speak to manager (grant this request — management should support your decision), or the situation escalates beyond a simple service refusal into broader disruption. Management should back up staff refusals and provide authority to enforce the decision.

Involve security (if available) or police when customer becomes physically aggressive or threatening, customer refuses to leave after being asked, you feel personally unsafe or threatened, other customers express concern or fear, or intoxicated customer is attempting to drive (in which case police should be called to prevent drunk driving). Never physically confront aggressive customers yourself. Your safety and other customers' safety takes priority. If necessary, retreat and call for professional assistance. Document incidents in writing: what happened, what you observed, what you said, customer's reaction, and outcome. This documentation protects you and the establishment if complaints or legal issues arise.

sections.heading: 5. Promoting Responsible Drinking
sections.content:
Beyond legal compliance, hospitality professionals can promote responsible drinking through positive practices. Responsible service is not about being moralistic or controlling customer choices, but about creating an environment where customers can enjoy alcohol safely without harm to themselves or others. Small interventions — offering food, suggesting water, slowing service pace, providing safe transportation options — can significantly reduce intoxication and related harms without diminishing customer experience. In fact, customers increasingly expect and appreciate responsible service as part of quality hospitality.

Promoting responsible drinking also protects the establishment's reputation and license. Venues known for over-serving, disorder, or allowing extreme intoxication attract negative attention from neighbors, authorities, and the public. Conversely, establishments with strong responsible service reputations attract customers who value safe, quality environments. Training all staff in responsible service, establishing clear policies, and creating a culture where safety is prioritized alongside hospitality creates long-term business benefits.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Offering Food and Water
subsections.content:
Food significantly slows alcohol absorption and reduces intoxication. Encourage customers to eat while drinking by highlighting food offerings, suggesting food pairings with drinks, offering complimentary snacks (olives, nuts, bread), and creating attractive food-and-drink combinations or menus. Never discourage food orders to increase alcohol sales — this is short-sighted and dangerous. In many cultures, including Spanish, eating while drinking is traditional and expected, making this intervention natural and culturally appropriate.

Offer water proactively. Many establishments provide tap water free of charge (in some regions, this is legally required). Bring water to tables without waiting to be asked. When serving rounds of drinks, include water glasses. Normalize water consumption: 'Here's water for the table' as a matter of course, not as a special request. Dehydration contributes to hangover severity and exacerbates intoxication's effects. Encouraging water consumption is simple, cost-free intervention that supports customer wellbeing. Never refuse reasonable requests for water as a tactic to encourage drink purchases — this is both legally problematic and ethically wrong.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Pacing Service and Avoiding Excessive Promotions
subsections.content:
Control service pace to prevent rapid intoxication. Avoid immediately serving next round before previous drinks are finished. When customers order multiple drinks for themselves, consider suggesting you bring them in sequence rather than all at once. For shots or high-alcohol drinks, avoid serving multiples simultaneously. If a customer is drinking rapidly, slow service by taking slightly longer to prepare next drink, engaging in brief conversation to create pause, or tactfully suggesting they might want to slow down: 'That's a strong drink, you might want to take your time with it.'

Avoid promotions that encourage rapid or excessive drinking: drinking contests or speed competitions, extreme quantity discounts encouraging bulk consumption, promotions rewarding finishing drinks quickly, or 'all you can drink' offers with unlimited alcohol for fixed price. These promotions increase intoxication, disorder, and liability. They are also prohibited in many regions. Instead, promote quality over quantity: tasting flights allowing sampling of different drinks in small portions, food-and-drink pairings encouraging slower consumption with food, and non-alcohol-focused events (live music, games) that provide entertainment beyond drinking.

subsections.heading: 5.3 Preventing Drink Spiking and Supporting Customer Safety
subsections.content:
Drink spiking (adding drugs or extra alcohol to someone's drink without their knowledge) is a serious crime and safety hazard. While responsibility for drink spiking rests with perpetrators, hospitality staff can take measures to prevent and respond to it. Train staff to watch for suspicious behavior (person tampering with unattended drink, person ordering drinks for someone who then becomes unexpectedly intoxicated). Encourage customers not to leave drinks unattended. If a customer reports feeling unexpectedly intoxicated or suspects their drink was spiked, take it seriously: offer assistance, call security or management, offer to call police or medical services if symptoms are severe, and preserve the drink as potential evidence if the customer wishes to report to police.

Broader safety support includes helping obviously intoxicated customers arrange safe transportation (calling taxi, helping them contact friends for pickup, ensuring they do not attempt to drive), watching for concerning situations (intoxicated person being led away by stranger, person too intoxicated to care for themselves), intervening tactfully in concerning situations or alerting security, and creating an overall environment where customers feel safe. These interventions go beyond minimum legal obligations, but they reflect the hospitality industry's broader responsibility for guest safety and wellbeing.

sections.heading: 6. Legal Protections and Liability
sections.content:
Servers refusing service in good faith compliance with law are legally protected from employer retaliation. An employer cannot fire, penalize, or discipline an employee for refusing to serve minors or intoxicated persons. Such retaliation would violate public policy and worker rights. If you refuse service based on reasonable assessment that customer is underage or intoxicated and management pressures you to serve anyway, document this, refuse to serve, and if penalized, consult union representative or labor lawyer about your rights.

Conversely, servers who serve minors or intoxicated persons face potential personal liability. Administrative fines can be imposed on individual servers, not just establishments. If your service of alcohol to an intoxicated person contributes to subsequent harm (traffic accident, assault), you could face civil liability (being sued for damages) and theoretically criminal liability in extreme cases of reckless disregard for obvious danger. Understanding these liability risks should motivate careful, responsible service decisions. When in doubt, err on caution and refuse service. The minor inconvenience or complaint from a refused customer is trivial compared to the legal, moral, and psychological consequences if your service contributes to serious harm.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Employer Support Obligations
subsections.content:
Employers must support staff in refusing service and must not create pressure to serve illegally. This includes establishing clear policies on ID checking and service refusal, training all staff in age verification and intoxication recognition, backing up staff decisions to refuse service when challenged by customers, providing security support to deal with aggressive customers who refuse to accept service denial, and never penalizing staff for refusing service in good faith compliance with law. Employers who pressure staff to serve minors or obviously intoxicated persons create liability for themselves and expose staff to personal liability.

If your employer creates a culture where refusing service is discouraged, complaints about refused customers are punished, or servers are expected to maximize sales regardless of customer condition, this is a serious problem. Document such pressure, raise concerns with management or human resources, and if pressure continues, consider reporting to labor inspectorate or consulting with union or legal representative. You have the right to comply with law without employer retaliation. In extreme cases where employer systematically requires illegal service, you may have grounds for justified resignation (allowing you to claim unemployment) based on employer's illegal demands.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Criminal Liability Risks
subsections.content:
While rare, criminal liability for alcohol servers can arise in extreme cases. Penal Code Article 368 criminalizes providing alcohol to minors in ways that endanger their health. Article 379 criminalizes reckless conduct creating serious risk to others. A server who knowingly serves obviously underage person or serves obviously intoxicated person who then drives and causes fatal accident could theoretically face criminal investigation. Actual prosecutions of individual servers (as opposed to establishment owners or managers) are uncommon, but the possibility exists.

Protecting yourself from criminal liability requires refusing service when legally required, documenting concerning situations (if customer becomes aggressive when refused service and makes threats, document the incident), reporting systematic problems to management and authorities if employer pressures illegal service, and seeking legal advice if you become aware of investigation or legal action. Criminal liability typically requires knowledge or recklessness — serving someone who you didn't realize was underage despite reasonable ID check is unlikely to result in criminal liability. However, deliberately serving someone you know is 15 years old, or serving obviously falling-down drunk customer another round knowing they intend to drive, could cross into criminal recklessness if harm results.

subsections.heading: 6.3 Insurance and Indemnification
subsections.content:
Establishments should carry liability insurance covering alcohol service risks. This insurance typically protects both the establishment and employees acting within scope of employment from civil liability for incidents related to alcohol service (e.g., if sued by victim of drunk driving accident involving patron). However, insurance may not cover intentional misconduct or violations of law. A server who deliberately serves minors or ignores obvious intoxication may find that insurance does not cover resulting liability.

Some employers indemnify (promise to protect) employees from liability arising from work duties. If your employer offers indemnification for responsible service decisions, ensure it is in writing and understand its scope. However, indemnification does not protect against personal criminal liability or administrative fines imposed personally on servers. The best protection is simply refusing service when required by law. No amount of insurance or indemnification is worth the moral burden of knowing your service contributed to someone's injury or death. Professional responsible service is ultimately about values and ethics, not just legal compliance.

items: Establish clear ID checking policy: Challenge 25 or Challenge 30 (check ID for anyone appearing under that age)
Display signage informing customers of ID checking policy
Train all staff in acceptable ID types: DNI, NIE, passport, EU driving license
When customer appears under threshold age, request ID politely but firmly: 'I need to see your ID please'
Check that photo matches customer, date of birth confirms age 18+, and document appears genuine
If customer refuses to provide ID, politely refuse alcohol service: 'I'm sorry, without ID I cannot serve you alcohol'
If ID appears fake or suspicious, refuse to accept it and decline service
Never confiscate suspected fake IDs; simply refuse service
Be consistent: check ID for all customers meeting threshold criteria, not selectively
If uncertain about a situation, consult manager before serving
Document any incidents involving suspected underage service attempts

checklists.title: Intoxication Recognition and Service Refusal Checklist

Watch for physical signs: unsteady gait, slurred speech, impaired coordination, glassy eyes, drowsiness

If signs of intoxication appear, refuse further alcohol service

State refusal clearly: 'I'm sorry, I cannot serve you any more alcohol'
Offer alternatives: water, coffee, soft drinks, food
Offer assistance: calling taxi, contacting friend for pickup, ensuring safe departure

If customer becomes aggressive, call security or manager; do not physically confront

bestPractices: Make ID checking a routine habit for all young-appearing customers; consistency reduces conflict and discrimination concerns

Practice service refusal language and techniques during training; being prepared reduces anxiety when real situations arise

glossary.Servicio Responsable de Alcohol: Responsible alcohol service — professional practices minimizing harm from alcohol consumption
glossary.Menor de Edad: Minor — person under 18 years, to whom alcohol service is absolutely prohibited
glossary.Estado de Embriaguez: State of intoxication — visible impairment from alcohol requiring service refusal
glossary.Documento Nacional de Identidad (DNI): National Identity Document — primary ID for Spanish citizens
glossary.Número de Identidad de Extranjero (NIE): Foreigner Identity Number — ID for foreign residents in Spain
glossary.Bebida Alcohólica: Alcoholic beverage — any drink containing ethanol, subject to service restrictions
glossary.Límite de Edad: Age limit — minimum age 18 for alcohol purchase and consumption in commercial settings
glossary.Sanción Administrativa: Administrative penalty — fine or other sanction imposed by authorities for regulatory violations
glossary.Responsabilidad Civil: Civil liability — legal responsibility to compensate for harm caused by one's actions or negligence
glossary.Spiking/Adulteración de Bebidas: Drink spiking — crime of adding drugs or extra alcohol to someone's drink without their knowledge
